articles.headline: Support for Clinton Wanes as Obama Sees Finish Line
articles.snippet: Hillary Rodham Clinton struck a publicly defiant posture, while some of her advisers acknowledged privately that they remained unsure about the future of her candidacy.
articles.abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton struck a publicly defiant posture, while some of her advisers acknowledged privately that they remained unsure about the future of her candidacy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton struck a publicly defiant posture on Wednesday about continuing her presidential bid despite waning support from Democratic officials and donors. Some of her advisers acknowledged privately that they remained unsure about the future of her candidacy.
articles.byline: By Patrick Healy and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Gadget Fanatics, Take Note
articles.snippet: Putting pen to paper may eventually go the way of eight-track tapes. Here comes the digital Pulse smartpen from LiveScribe.
articles.abstract: Putting pen to paper may eventually go the way of eight-track tapes. Here comes the digital Pulse smartpen from LiveScribe.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sooner or later, almost everything goes digital: cameras, camcorders, music players, TV, books, you name it.

articles.headline: Myanmar Faces Pressure to Allow Major Aid Effort
articles.snippet: An American diplomat warned of the possibility that the death toll could rise sharply, and a French diplomat urged the U.N. to force Myanmar to accept aid.
articles.abstract: An American diplomat warned of the possibility that the death toll could rise sharply, and a French diplomat urged the U.N. to force Myanmar to accept aid.
articles.lead_paragraph: BANGKOK  As hungry, shivering survivors waited among the dead for help after a huge cyclone in Myanmar, aid agencies and diplomats said Wednesday that the delivery of relief supplies was being slowed by the reluctance of the country’s secretive military leaders to allow an influx of outsiders.

articles.headline: Raid on Sect in Texas Rattles Other Polygamists
articles.snippet: Rumors of a Texas-style police crackdown are common in the hothouse world of religious polygamy.
articles.abstract: Rumors of a Texas-style police crackdown are common in the hothouse world of religious polygamy.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLORADO CITY, Ariz.  As the supper dishes were being cleared away and the rice pudding brought out for dessert, Marvin Wyler’s two wives, along with some of their children and a group of friends, began poring over the list.
articles.byline: By Kirk Johnson and John Dougherty

articles.headline: Oil Giants to Settle Water Suit
articles.snippet: A dozen oil companies agreed to pay $423 million in cash plus clean-up costs to settle litigation over groundwater contamination from the gasoline additive, MTBE.
articles.abstract: A dozen oil companies agreed to pay $423 million in cash plus clean-up costs to settle litigation over groundwater contamination from the gasoline additive, MTBE.
articles.lead_paragraph: Some of the nation’s largest oil companies have agreed to pay about $423 million in cash to settle a lawsuit brought by more than a hundred public water providers, claiming water contamination from a popular gasoline additive.

articles.headline: BlackRock Is Fix-It Firm to Manage Risky Assets of Others in Distress
articles.snippet: Under the aegis of the Fed, BlackRock is managing $30 billion of hard-to-sell assets from Bear Stearns. If it fumbles, the Fed, and by extension taxpayers, could lose billions.
articles.abstract: Under the aegis of the Fed, BlackRock is managing $30 billion of hard-to-sell assets from Bear Stearns. If it fumbles, the Fed, and by extension taxpayers, could lose billions.
articles.lead_paragraph: One Saturday morning in March, Laurence D. Fink got some urgent news: Wall Street needed his help.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: A Long List of Big Issues for F.A.A.
articles.snippet: The F.A.A. is confronting long-term questions about whether it should act more like a tough regulator, rather than a partner, of the airlines.
articles.abstract: The F.A.A. is confronting long-term questions about whether it should act more like a tough regulator, rather than a partner, of the airlines.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  With its more rigorous oversight of airplane maintenance having led to the recent grounding of thousands of flights, the Federal Aviation Administration is confronting long-term questions about whether it should act more like a tough regulator, rather than a partner, of the airlines.

articles.headline: Wave of Lawsuits Over Losses Could Hit a Wall
articles.snippet: Finding someone to sue over losses in the mortgage market and the credit crisis is easy. Winning in court, lawyers say, will be hard.
articles.abstract: Finding someone to sue over losses in the mortgage market and the credit crisis is easy. Winning in court, lawyers say, will be hard.
articles.lead_paragraph: Finding someone to sue over losses in the mortgage market and the credit crisis is easy. Winning in court, lawyers say, will be hard.

articles.headline: Violence in Zimbabwe Disrupts Schools and Aid
articles.snippet: Zimbabwe’s ruling party has broadened its campaign of intimidation to include teachers and aid workers.
articles.abstract: Zimbabwe’s ruling party has broadened its campaign of intimidation to include teachers and aid workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG  Zimbabwe’s ruling party, bent on retaining control after 28 years in power, has broadened its campaign of intimidation and violence to include teachers and even aid workers, disrupting education and basic care for tens of thousands of children across the country, according to humanitarian groups, union officials and the teachers themselves.
